contentrichtext.text: '''Grenville Davey''' (born 28 April 1961) is an English sculptor and winner of the 1992 [[Turner Prize]]. Davey is a visiting professor of the [[University of the Arts London]] and programme leader, MA Fine Art at the [[University of East London]].<ref>{{cite web| last= | first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title = AVA Staff â€” Academic Staff| work =| publisher = University of East London| date =| url = http://www.uel.ac.uk/ava/staff/index.htm| doi =| accessdate = 2010-01-31}}</ref> From December 2010 he became resident artist at the physics department of [[Queen Mary, University of London]], working with Dr David Berman. Grenville is the artist-in-residence at the [[Isaac Newton Institute for Mathematical Sciences]] from January to June 2012.<ref>{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title = Artist-in-residence| work =| publisher = Isaac Newton Institute for Mathematical Sciences| date =| url = http://www.newton.ac.uk/art/gdavey/| format =| doi =| accessdate = 2012-03-06}}</ref> ==Life== Born in [[Launceston, Cornwall|Launceston]], Cornwall, Davey first studied art in [[Exeter, England|Exeter]] before going to [[Goldsmiths College]] in [[London]] in 1985 where he took a BA in fine art. His first solo show was at the Lisson Gallery in London in 1987.<ref name="artist's profile">[http://www.terminartors.com/artistprofile/Davey_Grenville artist's profile]</ref> Davey is single and has one child. ==Work== Davey's work is influenced by the work of sculptors such as [[Tony Cragg]] and [[Richard Deacon (sculptor)|Richard Deacon]] and shows a similar interest in industrial materials. The simplicity of his forms shows an affinity with [[minimalism]]. Many of his works make references to everyday objects which if exhibited in themselves would be [[readymade]]s. ''Button'', a metre and a half wide clothes button made in steel, is a typical early work. Later works, such as ''Gold (Table)'' (a table as tall as a human) are larger in size. Primarily a sculptor, Davey produced a series of 12 prints with five other artists including etchings and screenprints.<ref name="artist's profile"/> ==Awards== Davey won the Tate's [[Turner Prize]] in 1992.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.independent.co.uk/uk/this_britain/article3019128.ece | work=The Independent | location=London | title=What's the point of the Turner Prize? | date=October 2, 2007 | accessdate=May 4, 2010}}</ref> Entitled ''HAL'', the work comprised two abstract steel objects, each measuring 244 x 122 cm (96 x 48 in). ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.uel.ac.uk/ava Architecture and the Visual Arts] {{New British Sculpture}} {{Authority control|VIAF=25406411}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Davey, Grenville | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = British artist | DATE OF BIRTH = April 28, 1961 | PLACE OF BIRTH = Launceston, Cornwall | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Davey, Grenville}} [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:English sculptors]] [[Category:Contemporary sculptors]] [[Category:20th-century sculptors]] [[Category:21st-century sculptors]] [[Category:Turner Prize winners]] [[Category:Alumni of Goldsmiths, University of London]] [[Category:People from Cornwall]] {{UK-sculptor-stub}}
